learning_outcomes.description: Know how to use geochemical surveys in order to understand geochemical processes in the surficial environment.
Know how to collect geochemical information in the field.
Organise sample material, submit to a laboratory and ensure appropriate quality control in the process
Receive geochemical data, organise the data, interpret the data, report on the results with the aim of answering geological or environmental questions
Apply the knowledge gained to a real life situation
Make an oral presentation covering the collection, interpretation of data and results obtained in geochemical surveys.

assessments.assessment_title: Reports and presentations of practical activities (Pinjarra Hills soil sampling and Samarco case study)
assessments.due_date:
1. Pinjarra Hills soil sampling report and presentation 8/09/2025 2:00 pm

2.Samarco case study: due date for the report 21/10/2025 2:00 pm
assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution, Practical/ Demonstration, Presentation
assessments.task_description:
Task 1: Pinjarra Hills (Group Work)

Students will dig a hole to collect soil samples, record the sample location using GPS, and describe the soil profile. Samples collected on different soil horizons will be analysed with a hand-held XRF. PhD and Eh will be measured on-site.

The students will prepare a summary report (one report per group) that describes the sampling methodology, reports the results, and interprets the collected data. The report must be submitted via Turnitin.

Task 2: Samarco Case Study (Group Work)

The students will investigate the source of potentially toxic elements reported in the sediments of the Doce River after the failure of Samarco's tailings dam. They will review the literature and watch videos about the incident. There will be straightforward questions that must be answered and submitted in a Word document via Turnitin.

The in-semester and the end of semester exams will contain questions about both tasks.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The in-semester exam is a closed-book exam that consists of multiple-choice and open questions covering the contents of Weeks 1 to 6.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution, Poster
assessments.task_description:
Students will investigate the stream sediments at Mt Coot-tha to determine if they contain potentially toxic elements above the environmental guidelines thresholds. Alternatively, they will have the option to explore the potential for gold mineralisation at Mt Coot-tha.

They will design a stream sediment survey, execute the sampling, and submit the collected samples to a geochemical laboratory. They will then assess the geochemical data and prepare a report summarising the survey. Major outcomes will be presented in a poster session.

The group report must be submitted via Turnitin. The poster must be submitted to the course coordinator via email. Students must print their poster and bring it to class on the designated presentation date. Only one student per group needs to submit the report on Turnitin.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The report must be submitted via Turnitin. The poster must be printed and presented in class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Multiple-choice and open questions, closed-book exam covering the theory presented from weeks 1 to 11. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Why Exploration and Environmental Geochemistry

The introductory section addresses the cycles of matter and the definition of reservoirs and fluxes. It covers the concepts of primary and secondary geochemical halos, elemental associations in geological processes and pathfinder elements. The convergence of exploration and environmental geochemistry in the surficial environment is explained.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Why Exploration and Environmental Geochemistry The introductory section addresses the cycles of matter and the definition of reservoirs and fluxes. It covers the concepts of primary and secondary geochemical halos, elemental associations in geological processes and pathfinder elements. The convergence of exploration and environmental geochemistry in the surficial environment is explained.

learning_activities.topic:
Review of minerals and rocks

Lecture covering main rock and ore-forming minerals, and major igneous rock types, followed by a practical session on identifying the main types of rocks. This lecture is facultative for Earth Sciences students.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Review of minerals and rocks Lecture covering main rock and ore-forming minerals, and major igneous rock types, followed by a practical session on identifying the main types of rocks. This lecture is facultative for Earth Sciences students.

learning_activities.topic:
Weathering and erosion the drivers of dispersion - Drivers of metal mobility

Factors that influence weathering (climate, bio-activity, rock type, geomorphology, time) and erosion (relief, rock type, climate and biota).

Drivers of Matter’s Mobility in Aqueous Solutions

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Chemical Weathering: From rock to soil

The processes leading from rock to soil is dealt with by discussing the stability of rock-forming minerals and mobility of the major elements. What is soil? Different types of soil: soil classification

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05

Introduction to Microbiology

Lectures and practical exercises introduce Microbiology and the' role of microprobes in weathering processes and elemental mobility.

learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction to Microbiology Lectures and practical exercises introduce Microbiology and the' role of microprobes in weathering processes and elemental mobility.

Assess SAMARCO's tailings dam burst and its impact on the environment from a geochemical point of view

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 11 To Week 12(13 Oct - 26 Oct)
learning_activities.topic:
Evaluation of geochemical anomalies

Application of basic statistics to identify errors in a geochemical database. Practical exercise in IoGas using univariate and multivariate statistics to identify geochemical anomalies.

Lecture addressing the interpretation of geochemical anomalies from an environmental perspective. Introducing the legislation about assessment levels for contaminants (National Environment Protection (Assessment of Site Contamination) Measure 1999 Schedule B1.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Evaluation of geochemical anomalies Application of basic statistics to identify errors in a geochemical database. Practical exercise in IoGas using univariate and multivariate statistics to identify geochemical anomalies. Lecture addressing the interpretation of geochemical anomalies from an environmental perspective. Introducing the legislation about assessment levels for contaminants (National Environment Protection (Assessment of Site Contamination) Measure 1999 Schedule B1.
